page.title: 02Local History
page.content: In Saxon times, even before William the Conqueror came to Britain, Bywell had two churches, St. Peters' and St.Andrews'. St. Andrews' was the mother church of this area. On Sundays the people from The Riding and Broomhaugh had to walk to Bywell to the church. When the railway opened people from Newcastle moved here and they decided they deserved a church of their own. So St. James' church was built in 1856. It was quite small at first but then the people decided to enlarge it, so they built two transcepts, one big one for the congregation and a smaller one for the organ. There is also a Methodist Chapel in the village. It was bought from the Baptists in 1966 and was then 123 years old, although the graveyard was first used in about 1700 A.D.
